markdownRemark.html:
For those who don‚Äôt know, I‚Äôm a Computer Science major and I enjoy programming outside of school and work. There‚Äôs something about getting to make whatever you want while also having total ownership of a project that makes building side projects so addicting. I‚Äôve heard it compared to other hobbies such as gaming or playing sports. Although many side projects may go unfinished or unreleased, I feel as though there is still a lot of experience to gain just from starting the project in the first place. In this post, I will walk you through my process of coming up with an idea of what to make, taking said idea and turning it into something tangible, to putting the project out in the world.

Coming Up with an Idea üí°

In order to build something, you first need an idea. I find this to be one of the hardest parts of side projects. This is simply because if there is no idea, there can‚Äôt be a project. To get around this potential roadblock, I like to examine my own daily life and see what areas I could possibly speed up or improve. Having intimate knowledge of the problem you‚Äôre trying to solve will make building a side project that much more easy.

Preliminary Research üßê

Once I have an idea in mind, I like to see what existing solutions already exist. Now, if I find more than a few existing projects that solve the same issue that I was hoping to tackle, then I ususally will not continue with that project. This is one of those situations that I mentioned earlier where I‚Äôm sort of peculiar - the fact that there are already projects that try and solve an issue means that your idea has already been validated. I find that if I do try and tackle such problems, I will often mimic the existing projects‚Äô solutions rather than building something unique. This can be a good practice initially, but I‚Äôve found that relying too much on this method then makes it harder for me to build projects with unique solutions later on.

Choosing a Tech Stack ü•û

Now that I have an idea and know I want to commit to this side project, the next thing I do is research what tech stack I will use to turn the idea into a real thing. This step assumes you‚Äôve also already determined the area or type of project you are going to make - be it a browser extension, CLI tool, a web or mobile app, etc. I love JavaScript and thanks to the runtime environment Node.js, I can make projects for almost all types of ‚Äúareas‚Äù (???). With the language selected, I then will decide if I want to use any libraries that could help speed up the development time and if I‚Äôm unfamiliar with a particular library, I will read their docs.

Coding ‚Üí MVP ü¶¥

Time for the fun part - coding! With an idea in mind and the right tools selected to build said idea, I get to work. Programming can be a double-edged sword when creating a side project: when it‚Äôs going well I love it, but when I get stuck on an issue that I can‚Äôt immediately solve, I also really hate it. Throughout the development process, these two emotions seem to constantly manifest and replace one another. At times I can feel so defeated by a bug and want to give up entirely only to get the biggest boost of confidence after stepping away and figuring out how to squash the bug. Making side projects can feel like war - it‚Äôs essentially a series of battles composed of wins and losses, me versus my code.

Eventually I come out victorious and emerge with something that works and solves the original problem. This will almost always be a minimum viable product, or MVP. The MVP serves as the skeleton for the finished product without all the bells and whistles that will eventually make it complete.

Break from Code - Design Time üé®

This is the step in the process where I like to start thinking about how I will market my side project. Like a newborn baby, the project needs a name. This can be as simple or extravagent as you would like - I‚Äôve been on both ends of the spectrum. Once a name is selected, I think about branding. What will the main colors of the project be (if applicable)? What graphic or logo can best represent this project? What font? Having answers to those questions then allows me to put my creativity to use. Using design software (I‚Äôm a big fan of Sketch), I will put together a press kit or package of promotional material (namely good looking graphics) to be used later on for open graph meta tags or product launches on sites like Product Hunt or Reddit.

Wrapping Up üéÄ

Seem like a long process yet? Luckily, we‚Äôre just about done. After my creative sprint, I go back to programming and flesh out the MVP. On goes the remaining features I thought would be useful and any bug fixes that are critical - there are always bugs - do not try to fix them all before ever launching you product.

Launching üöÄ

By now, I have a finished product and am ready to show it to the world. With the press kit I made earlier, I hit up several relevant subreddits to the project I just made an create posts that describe what the project is, why I made it, and where to find it. Posting on Reddit will give my project some exposure and feedback that I can then use to fix or tweak before launching on Product Hunt.

Looking Ahead üî≠

After having gone through this entire process several times and starting the process but not finishing many more times, I feel as though there is room for improvement.

Firstly, deciding whether or not to build something based on the number of existing projects is kind of silly. Even if there are many solutions out there, your take and solution to the problem is unique and therefore could end up being a better solution than all of the other projects.

Lastly, it‚Äôs really important to get your project out in the hands of the public as soon as possible as this will significantly improve your chances of actually completing it. Too many times to count have I worked on a project in isolation without letting others try it which resulted in a ‚Äúfailed‚Äù launch. This is simply due to the fact that I assumed I knew what people would want, rather than actually letting them tell me. A costly mistake if you‚Äôre hoping to have users other than yourself use the project.

Looking ahead, I hope to work on the above issues while also continually improving the process I‚Äôve since been following. I feel as though the side projects I‚Äôve made up until this point have been quite small in scope, so in the future I also plan on taking on larger problems that require more complex solutions. Finally, I would love to make something that I can monetize and earn some extra side income. That‚Äôs definitely a goal for 2019.
